Behaviors

Narrowing the treatment gap with equitable access: Mid-term outcomes of a community case management program in Cameroon

Littrell M, Moukam LV, Libite R, Youmba JC, Baugh G
Health Policy and Planning, 2013, 28 (7): 705-716
Location East region of Cameroon
Population Households with children under age 5
Intervention Description Community case management for childhood ilnesses. CCM package provided community-based diagnosis, treatment and referral for suspected malaria with artemisinin combination therapy (ACT) and diarrhoeal disease with ORS and zinc through community health workers (PSI)
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Awareness, access, and attitudes towards CHW services among caregivers improved with intervention

Behaviors: Children living in intervention vs comparison areas were significantly more likely to receive treatment at a public health facility or through a CHW for fever and diarrhea Appropriate treatment was significantly higher among children in intervention vs comparison areas including: antimalarial treatment for fever , ACT for fever , ORS for diarrhea and zinc for diarrhea
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Behavior, Method mix

Evaluation of a social marketing intervention promoting oral rehydration salts in Burundi

Kassegne S, Kays MB, Nzohabonayo J
BMC Public Health, 2011, 11 (155): 1-13
Location Burundi
Population Females of reproductive age from 30 households from each of the 115 "collines" in Burundi
Intervention Description PSI led this Social marketing intervention to promote the use of ORASEL for children under five. Campaign included mass media promotion and community outreach
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Positive changes in behavioral determinants associated with ORASEL use

Behaviors: ORASEL use among caregivers at their children’s last diarrheal episode increased significantly from 20% in 2006 to 30% in 2007
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5:Behavior Customer orientation, Insight, Theory, Mixed methods,

National scale-up of zinc promotion in Nepal: Results from a post-project population-based survey

Wang W, MacDonald VM, Paudel M, Banke KK
Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition, 2011, 29 (3): 207-217
Location 30 focus districts in Nepal
Population Households surveys with children under 6 years of age
Intervention Description The Social Marketing Plus for Diarrhoeal Disease Control: Point of Use Water Disinfection and Zinc Treatment (POUZN) project; Survey regarding knowledge and beliefs about zinc treatment after tha airing of a national mass-media campaign
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Over half (53.1%) of all caregivers (n=3,550) interviewed had heard about zinc products; most (97.1%) of those who had heard of zinc knew that zinc should be used for the treatment of diarrhea

Behaviors: At follow-up, the majority (67.5%) of children (n=289), aged less than six years, with diarrhoea were treated with ORS, and 15.4% were treated with zinc. Children whose caregivers recalled the mass-media message that zinc should be used for 10 days and whose caregivers perceived that zinc is easy to obtain were more likely to be treated with zinc for 10 days, along with ORS
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Behavior, Theory, Customer orientation, Insight Mixed methods

Determinants of use of household-level water chlorination products in rural Kenya, 2003-2005

DuBois AE, Crump JA, Keswick BH, Slutsker L, Quick RE, Vulule JM, Luby SP
International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 2010, 7 (10): 3842-3852
Location Nyanza Province, Kenya
Population Users and non-user controls of a new household water treatment product regarding drinking water and socioeconomic factors from 10 Villages with 1,452 compounds
Intervention Description Use of socially marketed household water treatment systems: flocculent-disinfectant and sodium hypochlorite
Outcomes

Behaviors: Reports of ever using the sodium hypochlorite solution ranged from 21% to 59%, while rates of use in the past 7 days ranged from 7% to 27%
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Segmentation, Exchange, Method mix

Shame or subsidy revisited: Social mobilization for sanitation in Orissa, India

Pattanayak SK, Yang J,Dickinson KL, Poulos C, Patil SR, Mallick RK, Blitstein JL, Praharaj P
Bulletin of the World Health Organization, 2009,87:580–587
Location India
Population Households
Intervention Description Intensive IEC campaign that used social marketing strategies and community led total sanitation
Outcomes

Behaviors: Latrine ownership did not increase in control villages, but in treatment villages it rose from 6% to 32% in the overall sample, from 5% to 36% in households below the poverty line and from 7% to 26% in households above the poverty line
Design Experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 6
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 7: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix

Increasing equity of access to point-of-use water treatment products through social marketing and entrepreneurship: A case study in western Kenya

Freeman MC, Quick RE, Abbott DP, Ogutu P, Rheingans R
Journal of Water & Health, 2009, 7 (3): 527-534
Location Nyanza Province, Kenya
Population 487 randomly selected households in eight communities served by the women’s groups
Intervention Description Safe Water System is a simple, inexpensive, point-of-use (POU) household water quality intervention using: 1) locally produced sodium hypochlorite solution for water treatment; 2) safe storage with containers with a narrow mouth, tight fitting lid and tap; and 3) behaviour change communications; women’s groups in western Kenya were trained to educate neighbours and sell health products to generate income (PSI)
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Knowledge of water treatment products was high

Behaviors: 20% (range 5–39%) of households in eight communities purchased and used chlorine, as confirmed by residual chlorine observed in stored water
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria X: Exchange, Method mix

Diarrhoea prevention in a high-risk rural Kenyan population through point-of-use chlorination, safe water storage, sanitation

Garrett V, Ogutu P, Mabonga P, Ombeki S, Mwaki A, Aluoch G, Phelan M, Quick RE
Epidemiology and Infection, 2008, 136 (11): 1463-1471
Location Nyanza Province, Kenya
Population Comparison of diarrhoea rates in 960 children aged <5 years in 556 households in 12 randomly selected intervention villages and six randomly selected comparison villages during weekly home visits over an 8-week period
Intervention Description Social Marketing to promote the Safe Water System (SWS) in collaboration with CARE Kenya's program to provide latrines and rainwater collection
Outcomes

Behaviors: Intervention households were also more likely to have residual chlorine in their stored water (43%of visits vs. 0%) and to possess a latrine (49% of visits vs. 27%)

Health: On multivariate analysis, chlorinating stored water [relative risk (RR)0.44, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.28–0.69], latrine presence (RR 0.71, 95% CI 0.54–0.92), rainwater use (RR 0.70, 95% CI 0.52–0.95), and living in an intervention village (RR 0.31, 95%CI 0.23–0.41), were independently associated with lower diarrhea risk
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Behavior, Exchange, Insight, Methods mix

Bringing safe water to remote populations: An evaluation of a portable point-of-use intervention in rural Madagascar

Ram PK, Kelsey E, R, Miarintsoa RR, Rakotomalala O, Dunston C, Quick RE
American Journal of Public Health, 2007, 97 (3): 398-400
Location Tamatave Province, Madagascar
Population Respondents from 242 households in 4 villages were interviewed
Intervention Description Social marketing campaign to promote SWS and SurEau water disinfectant. Campaign used community based sales agents
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Respondents from 239 households (99%) had heard of Sûr’Eau, the SWS disinfectant

Behaviors: 226 (95%) reported having ever used Sûr’Eau, and 166 (73%) reported current use. Current Sûr’Eau use was confirmed in 54% of households
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Behavior, Exchange, Methods mix

Sustained high levels of stored drinking water treatment and retention of hand-washing knowledge in rural Kenyan households following a clinic-based intervention

Parker AA, Stephenson R, Riley PL, Ombeki S, Komolleh C, Sibley L, Quick R
Epidemiology and Infection, 2006, 134 (5): 1029-1036
Location Homa Bay, Kenya
Population Clinic clients
Intervention Description Nurses in a maternal and child health clinic were trained in household water chlorination with a locally available, social marketed product, and in six steps of proper hand washing. Nurses initiated client education sessions on the SWS, hand-washing techniques, and diarrhoea prevention messages at the MCH clinic
Outcomes

Behaviors: After 2 weeks, free chlorine residuals were present in stored drinking water in 68 % of clients' homes and, 1 year later, in 71 % clients' homes. After 2 weeks, all six hand-washing steps were correctly demonstrated by 44 % of clients, and by 34 % 1 year later
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Behavior, Segmentation, Methods mix

Acceptability of and adherence to dispersible zinc tablet in the treatment of acute childhood diarrhoea

Nasrin D, Larson, CP, Sultana S, Khan, TU
Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition, 2005, 23 (3): 215-221
Location 4 sub-districts in Dhaka, Bangladesh
Population Children between the ages of 3 and 59 months and their caretakers
Intervention Description Distribution and sales of zinc tablets by a social marketing firm
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: The formulation was acceptable to children; 90.1% of 303 caretakers perceived that the tablets were equally or even more acceptable to their children compared to other medicines

Behaviors: Ninety-eight percent of the children received the standard dose of one tablet per day, 55.8% completed the full 10-day course of zinc treatment
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 1: Methods mix

Social marketing and motivational interviewing as community interventions for safe water behaviors: Follow-up surveys in Zambia

Thevos AK, Olsen SJ, Kaona FAD, Tembo M, Quick RE
International Quarterly of Community Health Education, 2002, 21 (1): 51-65
Location Ndola and Kitwe, Zambia
Population Peri-urban households
Intervention Description Volunteer community health promoters in experimental (social marketing + motivational interviewing) and comparison (social marketing only) groups trained in causes of diarrhea and prevention through use of Clorin and safe water storage by SFH/Zambia. Health promoters in experimental group additionally trained in MI techniques. After training, promoters conducted weekly household visits to promote and sell Clorin
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: At 3 mos FU, 68% of households in SM group knew of correct disinfectant use vs. 80% in SM+MI group (p>0.05). At 16 mos FU, 80% of households in SM group knew of correct disinfectant use vs. 89% in SM+MI group (p>0.05)

Behaviors: At 3 mos FU in Ndola,48% of households in SM group storing water safely vs. 87% in SM+MI group (p<0.01). At 16 mos FU in Kitwe, 63% of household in SM group stored water safely vs. 64% in SM+MI group (p>0.05)
Design Experimental
Sampling Method Probablity
Strength of Evidence Score 6
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Behavior, Theory

Evidence of behaviour change following a hygiene promotion programme in Burkina Faso

Curtis V, Kanki B, Cousens S, Diallo I, Kpozehouen, Sangare M, Nikiema M
Bulletin of the World Health Organization, 2001, 79 (6): 518-27
Location Bobo-Dioulasso, Burkina Faso
Population Mothers of children aged 0–35 months, older sisters, maids, and school-aged children
Intervention Description Social marketing campaign involving house-to-house visits, performance of plays, and school curriculum
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Improved knowledge

Behaviors: Safe disposal of children’s stools changed little between 1995 and 1998 (80% pre-intervention, 84% postintervention); hand-washing with soap after cleaning a child’s bottom rose from 13% to 31% and the proportion of mothers who washed their hands with soap after using the latrine increased from 1% to 17%
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Methods mix

Challenges in implementing a point-of-use water quality intervention in rural Kenya

Makutsa P, Nzaku K, Ogutu P, Barasa P, Ombeki S, Mwaki A, Quick RE
American Journal of Public Health, 2001, 91 (10): 1571-1573
Location Nyanza Province, Kenya
Population 24 villages
Intervention Description Behavior change campaign to promote use of Safe Water System included advertising tools such as posters and brochures, as well as puppet shows , skits, and public demonstrations
Outcomes

Behaviors: The project has resulted in adoption rates of 33.5% for chemical water treatment and 18.5% for clay pots modified for safe water storage
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, insight, Exchange, Competition, Method mix

Collaboration, cholera, and cyclones: A project to improve point-of-use water quality in Madagascar

Dunston C, McAfee D, Kaiser R, Rakotoarison D, Rambeloson L, Hoang AT, Quick RE
American Journal of Public Health, 2001, 91 (10): 1574-1576
Location Mahavita, Madagascar
Population CARE evaluated the program’s impact in Mahavita through baseline and follow-up surveys of a random sample of 375 households in 15 neighborhoods
Intervention Description CARE contracted PSI to socially market the Safe Water System; Campaign to increase sales of SurEau water treatment
Outcomes

Behaviors: The utilization rate of Sûr’Eau in Mahavita households was 11.2% after 6 months. Utilization in neighborhoods in the last stage of the community mobilization process was 19.7%, compared with 8.4% in those at an earlier stage (P=.01). Median free chlorine residuals in stored water were found to be 0.23mg/L in households using Sûr’ Eau, compared with 0.1 mg/L in households not using the product (P=.005)
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Methods mix

Analysis of different communication channels for promoting hygiene behavior

Pinfold JV
Health Education Research, 1998, 14 (5): 629-639
Location Six sub-districts in Khon Kaen Province, Thailand
Population Households from selected villages and random selection of schools - study used questionnaires and FGD
Intervention Description Social marketing campaign to improve hand and dish-washing practices. Campaign involved both a variety of media outlets as well as village-level health workers
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Strong correlation between number of communication channels remembered by respondents and knowledge

Behaviors: No significant improvements in behaviors outside of school children
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation, Mixed Methods

Measuring the effect of a hygiene behaviour intervention by behaviour and diarrhoeal disease

Pinfold JV, Horan NJ
Transactions of the Royal Socity of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene, 1996, 90 (4): 366-371
Location Khon Kaen Province, Thailand
Population Households in 37 village
Intervention Description A social marketing-based hygiene improvement campaign to promote hand washing, especially before feeding a baby, cooking, eating, and after defaecation or cleaning a baby’s bottom, and dish washing immediately after eating
Outcomes

Behaviors: There was a significant improvement in both behaviors in intervention versus control communities

Health: Diarrhea was less common in young children from the intervention villages, with 11 villages having lower incidence rates of diarrhea than 5 control villages; overall this amounted to a 39% reduction
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Exchange, Insight, Segmentation, Methods mix
